-NGp7YKs9Y0cYpjDfij1.description: There's a false path to the east here. Every time I've ever been at this point, the crew stops to debate which way to go. Scouting a minute down the false path reveals it's not a real path, so it's no big deal. But, the false path is usually muddy, so just keep that mind if it's really cold or a crewling has super-unwaterproofed boots.
-NGp7YKs9Y0cYpjDfij1.name: Ari

-Nc-PllG-3tG4ed-dWrk.name: Jack Proudfeet via Adam via Aster

-NGp7YKtLMXNcXBZmjjb.description: If facilitating solos at Flat Laurel, I think this is without a doubt the best place to set up base camp. You'll know it when you see it. It's huge. Like you can fit a whole Bearmuda triangle in the site. And it's flat. And has a river. And bear hang trees. And good solo sites nearby. There's another good site 2 minutes southeast on the trail, but this one is better.
-NGp7YKtLMXNcXBZmjjb.name: Ari

-NGp7YKtLMXNcXBZmjjc.description: In August 2012 and August 2013, there were issues with bees at a point along this trail. I can't say exactly where, but I would guess it was about half way between D Boone and Deep Gap. It was about 6 minutes past (coming from D Boone) a high impact site, and it was right by some steps made from logs.
-NGp7YKtLMXNcXBZmjjc.name: Ari

-NGp7YKuhzbmjFYZWnrY.description:
(this point is for testing/demonstration purposes)

Yeaaaahhhhh Boiiiiiii....HAWGS GONE WILD!!!!!!
-NGp7YKuhzbmjFYZWnrY.name: Unknown

-NbSokoj8-3s8A_FESI7.name: Adam
-NbSokoj8-3s8A_FESI7.text: It is quite good, can confirm. Lots of unique flavors :)

-NGp7YKuhzbmjFYZWnrZ.description: (this point is for testing/demonstration purposes)Mmmmm. Darn tootin good ice cream.
-NGp7YKuhzbmjFYZWnrZ.name: Unknown

-NGp7YKvvW9NfXQiSI-C.description: If you anticipate your crew being here, make sure to bring a sharpie on the trail.
-NGp7YKvvW9NfXQiSI-C.name: Ari

-NGp7YKvvW9NfXQiSI-D.description:
There is a natural rockbed waterslide that is just across the street from the Cove gate and no one from the institutional memories of 2013 knew it existed (discovered August 2012, Aisha knows where it is!). From the road, go a few steps down the trail leading to fish hatch and there should be a small side trail leading down to a campsite. Keep following the path through the right side of the campsite going away from the road and you should end up at a river spot with a narrow waterfall rockslide leading into a swimming hole. 

Mothers and their children were sliding down safely so our crew joined in on the fun, but it could be black zone to some.
-NGp7YKvvW9NfXQiSI-D.name: Ky~e

-NGp7YKwKOP1CheLHRcE.description: Pipe for water located on the jeep track at the Black Balsam parking lot
-NGp7YKwKOP1CheLHRcE.name: Ross

-NGp7YKxL2XX5d22THMg.description: There isn't much to be desired for camping spots around this area. So if crewlings are like yay gap we'll stop there for the night, try to non-directly push them away from that thought. Horse cove gap is about the same as welll
-NGp7YKxL2XX5d22THMg.name: Vern

-NrENh05cBW-hIYsXFTo.name: Adam
-NrENh05cBW-hIYsXFTo.text: I looked this up - the name of this is Avery Creek campsites / campground, managed by the forest service. It is free to camp, and it seems you don't make a reservation. Designed for tents. Busy in summer. Look on the forest service site for any updates. Not sure if it counts as dispersed camping (in the season people sometimes bring RVs), but perhaps. I found a thing saying it is closed in winter, but if some tired PWILD backpackers were to stumble in...

-NGp7YKxL2XX5d22THMh.description: Several high impact campsites. Small stream for water. Near the top of an awesome waterfall/cliff.
-NGp7YKxL2XX5d22THMh.name: Scott

-NGp7YKya-AJmDnlCNHI.description: Due to some unforeseen circumstances, my March 2014 crew was dropped off here. If for some reason you ever hike this trail, pack Chacos or Crocs - we did 8 legit, take-out-your-soles-and-unbuckle-your-pack river crossings in the span of a mile. In other news, though, there's a gorgeous campsite along this ridge. :)
-NGp7YKya-AJmDnlCNHI.name: Emily Stout

-NGp7YKzCD3jZ95r5pII.description: Pipe for water part way up the trail to Cold Mountain
-NGp7YKzCD3jZ95r5pII.name: Eleanor

-NdOFkYaKJ4P8XhQgAZG.name: Adam
-NdOFkYaKJ4P8XhQgAZG.text: Water higher up here might be full of sediment, we struggled with this in August 2023. If you go down further in the valley there is more water and it's clearer.

-NGp7YL-LTyaEV28q4Wu.description: Pipe for water slightly south of Shining Rock on Art Loeb. Not a lot of other water sources around.
-NGp7YL-LTyaEV28q4Wu.name: Eleanor

-NdORyZD0S97sKVceR_f.name: bkim
-NdORyZD0S97sKVceR_f.text: THERE ARE NO SPOTS HERE FOR AUGUST.

-NGp7YL0Qzj3ms8kKTn6.description: Camping at Ivestor Gap is quite windy and exposed. Not ideal for cold nights on March.
-NGp7YL0Qzj3ms8kKTn6.name: Eleanor

-NGp7YL18-WNCAf6_qJr.description: If starting at D-Boone make sure to get an early drop off and motivate your crew to get moving! First place to camp is Deep Gap and it's a long uphill battle to there.
-NGp7YL18-WNCAf6_qJr.name: Eleanor

-NGp7YL2Pl1AXCahMrnb.description: Incredible view and great photo spot that is often missed. Coming up from the wall-of-death, turn left towards Devil's Courthouse, take ~16 steps, and carefully walk down a little side trail on the left towards the edge.
-NGp7YL2Pl1AXCahMrnb.name: Ky~e

-NQqZiUA0QWzPtDJT0m4.name: Adam
-NQqZiUA0QWzPtDJT0m4.text: Can confirm this is the location of the awesome waterfall. It's really more like several waterfalls in a long cascade down through the valley

-NGp7YL5O9rATcOY2Idw.description:
There's a waterfall here which is one of my favorite places in Pisgah.

Note: it may actually be at the next valley, "BM AKW 227" on the USGS map. I can't actually remember - but if you're taking this trail you're gonna hit both, because there's no other way to go.

It's - sublime. Because it's one of those places that's always empty. This trail is rarely taken and somehow seems more 'primordial' than the others. You'll be laying in a little pool of water on the top of the falls and staring up into the towering greenth and you'll feel like you did on your first trip - like there's no civilization for twenty miles in every direction.

Also, we found a crayfish in the top of the falls here, which really makes me wonder. How could it have survived there? These streams filter down from the edge of the BRP. It and its brethren must have been in these hills for thousands or millions of years.

Note that this trail is especially tedious to reach from the road, so don't try anything silly.
-NGp7YL5O9rATcOY2Idw.name: Krkr

-NGp7YL6aBH1B0jqzRHa.description:
There's an excellent swimming hole around here which was dubbed 'Andy's Bridge of Death' years before I visited it - legend has it that someone named Andy broke their leg there by jumping off of the bridge.

Jumping off of the rocks is safe and lovely (try it in March!). But jumping off the bridge - no. Don't do that.

I was never clear on whether it was here or a bit up the trail, or if the 'Yellowstone Falls' marker is actually referring to it.
-NGp7YL6aBH1B0jqzRHa.name: Krkr

-NGp7YL7ZvyQJK6HIDHy.description: Great VAM. It's right on the trail, but isn't obvious. You need to climb over and onto the other side of the rock. You know you're at the spot I'm talking about because it's two steps before/after the open field on this trail.
-NGp7YL7ZvyQJK6HIDHy.name: Ari

-NOQuSs7tjv8hkMngaIP.name: Brennan
-NOQuSs7tjv8hkMngaIP.text:
Yes, definitely dank-ass
Super protected campsite in a clearing with a great view. Water is a little difficult to get to

-NQqf4WK7lQuQ80i-Hco.name: Adam
-NQqf4WK7lQuQ80i-Hco.text:
Beautiful campsite. Exact location marked with an X on the USGS map.

If going south on the Art Loeb, after crossing the road twice, start looking for switchbacks. At the west end of the first switchback, there is a big boulder that you can climb and look down into the campsite. It's a clearing surrounded by rocky cliffs on one side and rhododendrons on the other. The path to get in is at the next switchback's west point, through the rhododendrons.

If going north on the Art Loeb, from the road intersection the trail to get in is at the second west point of the switchbacks. Incidentally, there is a trail to a small flat clearing at the first west point, if you want to separate the tent and the kitchen more.

-NGp7YL7ZvyQJK6HIDHz.description: Dank-ass (aka good) campsite a couple switchbacks up from Glocester down to your left as you head up to Pilot. Hidden behind a big rock, has an epic view.
-NGp7YL7ZvyQJK6HIDHz.name: Bobby and Noelle

-NGp7YL8J8TAdB10knzD.description: Water here ranges from a small brook to nothing, depending on rain fall. If any, it will cross under the Art Loeb near the A-frame turn off closest to Pilot.
-NGp7YL8J8TAdB10knzD.name: Bobby

-NGp7YLAdLTgCIEFzoX1.description: This area is suuuper confusing (which lead to much chaos for the 2011 mongols)
-NGp7YLAdLTgCIEFzoX1.name: Bobby and Noelle

-NGp7YLDRhGIuWpRzklD.description: Sub-par campsite here, but It is the only one between Wagon Ridge and Graveyard fields.
-NGp7YLDRhGIuWpRzklD.name: Bobby

-NGp7YLEjOwR8SHwkQuW.description: Exxxxtremely steep trail. The real wall of death...
-NGp7YLEjOwR8SHwkQuW.name: Bobby and Noelle

-NGp7YLFPxmR_AdFdD6m.description: There is a campsite hidden above/behind a big rock next to the parking lot. It is really only big enough for 4 man tents, so def don't try to tarp there. Also...it is technically illegal since it is in the area bordering the BRP, so don't let rangers see you...
-NGp7YLFPxmR_AdFdD6m.name: Bobby

-NGp7YLGH1-gwpd4W0Uf.description: Turn off for the Fun Run
-NGp7YLGH1-gwpd4W0Uf.name: Bobby and Noelle

-NGp7YLITiAihhoiQicH.description: Epic hidden waterfall! Up the road a bit from where 105 hits the dirt road. Awesome to stop at if hiking into Cove.
-NGp7YLITiAihhoiQicH.name: Noelle

-NGp7YLJK01W3Z4_GqFB.description: If you've never seen it, it's not super obvious that there's a body of water and rocks to jump off here. You have cross the stream, and then it's obvious.
-NGp7YLJK01W3Z4_GqFB.name: Unknown

-NGp7YLLzpR0FXZrQXi0.description: Camped in a field at D-Boone in March 2014, thought we'd get in trouble with the ranger but instead he told us we could use the bathrooms in the heated dining hall. He did request that we check in with him in the future if we're planning to camp there for the night. Right now he lives in the camp master round house past the dining hall but is moving into a big house across the river next year, so go knock on his door for future march trips!
-NGp7YLLzpR0FXZrQXi0.name: Lizzie

-NGp7YLM904l9QP_fHg7.description: Good campsite on the trail going around Sassafras Knob (the trail is only labelled on the USGS). The trail going over the top of Sassafras Knob is only labelled on the Nat Geo.
-NGp7YLM904l9QP_fHg7.name: Tyler

-NGp7YLOJJA3TdTTQv89.description: 9 river crossings on a 1 mile stretch. Can be avoided with dirt road hiking
-NGp7YLOJJA3TdTTQv89.name: Isa Ferrall

-NGp7YLPjnaq0rZisVkV.description: Lots of river crossings on Trail 133. Consider taking southern trail (322) if cold weather in March.
-NGp7YLPjnaq0rZisVkV.name: Ali

-NM-V2m0sP1tTuNIg-yR.name: Klaudia Cabinles
-NM-V2m0sP1tTuNIg-yR.text:
This was renamed in 2015 to 'Arcadia', and has been the historic site of PWILD August base camp!! 

(Reference debrief notes around that time; institutional decision to not to refer to basecamp with the name of a real place)

Owing to permitting concerns, it was unknown whether the rangers would let us renew these group campsites (we technically operate under a backcountry permit). Maelan Zurilleon (PD M19, A19) and Klaudia (PD A21) found another campsite between 'I Can't Believe It's Not Butter Gap' and Arcadia. However, that entails more of a hike for truck access, which may slow response times for evacs and supply drop-offs.

-NGp7YLVC7TFfch8YW9S.description: Fox Mountain Guides (Where CD's get trained)
-NGp7YLVC7TFfch8YW9S.name: Bobby

-NQqjcERVIPP_Uf02KRj.name: Adam
-NQqjcERVIPP_Uf02KRj.text: Can get windy-cold in March (true of high-up gaps in general). Bringing a lightweight tarp to use as a wind break helps a lot.

-NGp7YLg3uCtFg0iR3Mx.description: Food hang torn down by "Berney" the black bear. August 2013. Pack found next day coated in a metric ton of bear slobber, torn to shreds. Berney went for the pancake mix/oatmeal, bypassed the summer sausage (note: sausage had not yet been massaged).
-NGp7YLg3uCtFg0iR3Mx.name: Bobby

-Ncnhn1TQKbnUUVO8E_p.name: Brennan
-Ncnhn1TQKbnUUVO8E_p.text: We camped here in A2023 – several good flat areas for camping.

-NGp7YLhiYX5WbgKf8mE.description: Enchanted forest--great tent/tarp sites. Step crewling may or may not have tossed his cookies (or in this case, his pesto pasta) here in 2012...
-NGp7YLhiYX5WbgKf8mE.name: Bobby

-NGp7YLiOEyGuKyTWZvl.description: Enchanted Forest--good place for the mongols to stay.
-NGp7YLiOEyGuKyTWZvl.name: Bobby

-NGp7YLiOEyGuKyTWZvm.description: Sam Knob Parking lot/toilet. Favored location for crazy jesus man. Typically a fair amount of drunk rednecks in August.  Site of the conclusion of the epic showdown "Bay wrastles the honey pot," August 2011. Watch for spiders in the toilets.
-NGp7YLiOEyGuKyTWZvm.name: Bobby

-NGp7YLky6sSij10xJ8Z.description: Old butt knob and dog loser knob, as the name entails, are not fun to hike and have really no good views. Better to go on the 363.
-NGp7YLky6sSij10xJ8Z.name: Vern

-NGp7YLky6sSij10xJ8_.description: Across the road from the Looking Glass trailhead, there's a really good water hole with a rock to jump from!
-NGp7YLky6sSij10xJ8_.name: Unknown

-NGp7YLm9lba9ILBE-PQ.description: Lolz no campsites anywhere over here
-NGp7YLm9lba9ILBE-PQ.name: Unknown

-NGp7YLpQUNxl2DCrg2H.description: There is a high impact campsite somewhere in this region to the left of the trail, next to the river.  It can be a good place to camp, but it is BLACK ZONE if it is raining or if you think it might rain.
-NGp7YLpQUNxl2DCrg2H.name: Unknown

-Nco3bKdSE1JQ0TlIlHq.name: Adam
-Nco3bKdSE1JQ0TlIlHq.text: For detailed / accurate trail intersections, see the Open Street Map (OSM) layer (and maybe screenshot it), or else you will be very confused. Also, at the center of Shining Rock gap there is an overgrown open area with two trail intersections right by each other (see this point's location on satellite view). This is good for knowing you are here since there aren’t signs labeling the gap.

-NGp7YLqgavwC__Qg0b4.description: Watch out in this area, the trail intersections are different on the USGS and the Nat Geo
-NGp7YLqgavwC__Qg0b4.name: Unknown

-NGp7YLt1Er1oeOqPR4X.description: If crewlings only have the Nat Geo, they may struggle finding the trailhead when coming from the Devil's Courthouse drop off.  Consider giving them the USGS
-NGp7YLt1Er1oeOqPR4X.name: Unknown

-NdODh9tBjI49PjL5T-e.name: DChou
-NdODh9tBjI49PjL5T-e.text: The vote for 363 is seconded - plenty of stops to get water along the trail.

-NGp7YLwNm-Y3ofM0dBp.description: If you have crew members with bad joints or foot blisters, avoid going down this route because there is some aggressive downhill after old butt knob.  Take the 363 instead
-NGp7YLwNm-Y3ofM0dBp.name: Unknown

-NdX9QzZDdFMGNkiuCpg.name: Adam
-NdX9QzZDdFMGNkiuCpg.text: I understand this is where the best VAMs are, instead of the very top of Shining Rock. See the OSM layer for trail details to figure out how to get here.

-NGp7YLxdja3fmKvV92e.description: To find the VAM you have to keep an eye out and climb some rocks, you will not find it if you stay on the main trail.
-NGp7YLxdja3fmKvV92e.name: Unknown

-NGp7YLxdja3fmKvV92f.description: Beware the USGS is horribly confusing/unclear in this area. On some PWILD USGS there are no trails marked, and on some there's a maze of trails marked.
-NGp7YLxdja3fmKvV92f.name: Ari

-NGp7YLyDGtvC52BsMGU.description:
Sunny Point Cafe. So good.

Parking directions from their website: We have a small parking lot adjacent to the restaurant, including two reserved accessible spaces. There is also an overflow lot next to our garden.
Free street parking is available in marked places along Haywood Road in both directions and down Dorchester Street and State Street. Please take note of signed no parking zones, especially near intersections.
-NGp7YLyDGtvC52BsMGU.name: Ari

-NKkkle6OJQbRhBHUXqr.name: Adam
-NKkkle6OJQbRhBHUXqr.text: The Gear Locker is no longer here; it's in the Swift parking garage. Interesting point for PWILD history though.

-NGp7YM-5zNMQqO8mZbr.description:
There is a great solo site behind a high impact site on the river near the waterfall. Be careful if you have solos during the weekend though, there might be randos. 
Also, if you give someone the cave as a solo site, watch out for strangers
-NGp7YM-5zNMQqO8mZbr.name: Unknown

-NrMxzE2C1LUyxsxFWfW.name: Adam
-NrMxzE2C1LUyxsxFWfW.text: If you don't feel like going over Sassafras Knob, you don't have to - there is a trail going around on the east side, not marked on the Nat Geo (see the OSM map).

-NGp7YM0SV-wYjPUx2J_.description: I always forget how steep this climb is until I'm on it and gasping for breath. Beware. Coming from Farlow Gap especially, getting over this mountain will take a while.
-NGp7YM0SV-wYjPUx2J_.name: Emily Stout

-NGp7YM19qYqSAghZfk0.description: AMAZING high impact campsite here. Flat, right next to a river, and lots of bearhang trees. Also a super cool suspension bridge.
-NGp7YM19qYqSAghZfk0.name: Emily Stout

-NGp7YM2Eqn3n3-jB9uw.description: Bring two liters of water if you ever hike up Looking Glass...
-NGp7YM2Eqn3n3-jB9uw.name: Unknown

-NGp7YM3eqgndiUC5R7-.description: Nothing to see here folks, just one of my favorite places to raise trout and christmas trees in the summer months.
-NGp7YM3eqgndiUC5R7-.name: Mr. Ziegler

-NGp7YM4fSNKUigYpo5i.description: You, my friend, are an adventurer. Keep being awesome and encourage others to similarly zoom out from a narrow perspective on life.
-NGp7YM4fSNKUigYpo5i.name: Mr. Ziegler

-NGp7YM7IjbpkFYsKWD6.description: Some would say that Patagonia is the last wild setting on Earth. Obviously they never had you kids stay on their porch!
-NGp7YM7IjbpkFYsKWD6.name: Mr. Ziegler

-NdNw0axX47PEi2kjKzx.name: Adam
-NdNw0axX47PEi2kjKzx.text: Maybe don't encourage nudity though, that's a no-no now in PWILD. Also camping not allowed here (Graveyard Fields) anymore.

-NGp7YM8_TA-Zv6kSgb6.description:
Agreed with Krkr, great rock to jump off into a deep pool, although it is sometimes crowded on weekends. If you want to semi-nondirectively encourage nudity, use the alternate name of Skinny Dip Falls. 
Also, there are a couple decent camp sites if you scout near the banks downstream.
-NGp7YM8_TA-Zv6kSgb6.name: Sludwig

-NGp7YM9uPXu-g12p4TI.description: Nice tent campsite on a sandy beach between the river and the Art Loeb. Good spot for an early morning pick-up at Davidson if you don't want to pay to camp at Davidson River Campground. Downside: being able to see cars zoom by on 276.
-NGp7YM9uPXu-g12p4TI.name: Sludwig

-NGp7YMAaqWf_CdC1FKH.description: In August 2013 we couldn't find the trailhead for 109 - the trail is there but I don't think it gets much use. Cross the river and bushwhack a bit up the (admittedly quite steep) bank, you'll find 109 running parallel to the river like the NatGeo shows. Enjoy the spider webs!
-NGp7YMAaqWf_CdC1FKH.name: Sludwig

-NdNxvkhAjPJ0fp5m6hi.name: Adam
-NdNxvkhAjPJ0fp5m6hi.text: See the Open Street Map (OSM) layer for accurate trail intersections.

-NGp7YMBvGRZffsBT8Kw.description: Not marked on NatGeo or USGS, but there is a connector trail to Devils Courthouse that takes you over the tunnel. Good signage and very obvious, only a 5-10 minute walk off the Mountains to Sea Trail to get to the top of Devil's Courthouse, instant VAM!
-NGp7YMBvGRZffsBT8Kw.name: Sludwig

-NGp7YMBvGRZffsBT8Kx.description: Eerily close to a pack of coyotes during the Wintry Mix of March 2014 - ate cold naan pizza because Pisgods did not answer pleas.
-NGp7YMBvGRZffsBT8Kx.name: Sludwig

-NGp7YMCAbTM8iKM_BbW.description: The trailhead here (for trail #113 Green Mountain) is extremely difficult to find. I think it's about 10 feet east of the bridge, but I'm not sure. Also, the trail is entirely on a ridge. And super steep for the first half mile.
-NGp7YMCAbTM8iKM_BbW.name: Ari

-NGp7YMEcVY9q4dykR0O.description: The climb to the top of the rock formation just to the west of the path here is 30 seconds. It's a VAM that's mildly decent but also has that extra rewarding feeling of finding something off the path.
-NGp7YMEcVY9q4dykR0O.name: Ari

-NGp7YMF_kgUhZVDYb3c.description: Yarr, here be water on the west side of the road coming out of a large pipe
-NGp7YMF_kgUhZVDYb3c.name: DChou

-NGp7YMHBxYgv7W87j5x.description: So uh, it doesn't necessarily look like it but 133 crosses the river literally (Not figuratively) 10 times without bridges so...if it's august do it during the day and it should be fine, but if it's march probably black zone. use bear hang cord to make a really long tarp line to give crewlings something to hold onto.
-NGp7YMHBxYgv7W87j5x.name: DChou

-NQqjEney3SU8f67OqeJ.name: Adam
-NQqjEney3SU8f67OqeJ.text: Agreed. Though not fun to walk down then up the steep climb from Farlow Gap when getting water.

-NdOCXtmXyfPlJS8h2uE.name: Adam
-NdOCXtmXyfPlJS8h2uE.text: Apparently this spot can run dry in August, especially if it hasn't rained for a while. One crew in August 2023 came here and the creek bed was completely dry.

-NGp7YMHBxYgv7W87j5y.description: Your best bet for water near farlow
-NGp7YMHBxYgv7W87j5y.name: DChou

-NGp7YMIzKW-rP4e2bCk.description: High impact tarp site, a little slopey. Go down the trail for meh bear hangs. Try not to let your crewlings cook on the BRP.
-NGp7YMIzKW-rP4e2bCk.name: Rezree Niiro

-NGp7YMKuo5EcYCTA2WU.description: They say that there's a rare flower that requires trace amounts of PWILD senior tears to grow. It's only been found here and in weird big circle patterns.
-NGp7YMKuo5EcYCTA2WU.name: Jaxxxon

-NGp7YMLi4FCiOpHhlZB.description: Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute. WHY HAVE WE NEVER GONE HERE?!
-NGp7YMLi4FCiOpHhlZB.name: Unknown

-NGp7YMOXBWQdoamu3_E.description: Did you know the capital of Djibouti is Djibouti?!
-NGp7YMOXBWQdoamu3_E.name: Ismaïl Omar Guelleh

-NGp7YMRR7ZqPbH4c5aS.description:
This road is entitled "Saddle Gap Road." On the USGS it is marked as leading to Saddle Gap. Alas, it is extremely overgrown, and leads nowhere. Don't lead hopeful crewlings up here in the middle of a night hike in the pouring rain.
xoxo Stout and Grant
-NGp7YMRR7ZqPbH4c5aS.name: Stout

-NGp7YMSKm_7AfV8mJn9.description: this climb is 10x steeper than it looks...lotsa fun with day 0 packs
-NGp7YMSKm_7AfV8mJn9.name: Unknown

-NGp7YMVR51x0NMws15r.description: aug 2014, 2 crewlings stung (i think by logs, but higher up from the area ari pointed out) be careful!
-NGp7YMVR51x0NMws15r.name: bkim

-NGp7YMWrMtoakwmGK0c.description: This would be a GREAT solo spot. This could be a pick up after solos to replace Mt. Pisgah and Pink Beds for solos. Go past the boggy area, past two small bridges, go up a hill and curve a bit before you get to the key spot. Explore and really go down some of the smaller little unofficial trails that come off the main one. There are great fire rings and large open areas that would work as a base camp and solo site. Not much foot traffic, came on a weekend.
-NGp7YMWrMtoakwmGK0c.name: Jamie Bando

-NGp7YMYbu53L1SrFJ42.description: There is a path around here that will take you up to sunny slab. This is only relevant if you can't tell distances very well.
-NGp7YMYbu53L1SrFJ42.name: Unknown

-NGp7YMZ2dVtUkIqiL3E.description: Hey Folks, there's a great little rock-slide waterfall that's fun for the whole family to slide down. Just keep heading towards the river through the campground that's just off the trail.
-NGp7YMZ2dVtUkIqiL3E.name: Mr. Ziegler

-NGp7YM_5gtV_OLqH9kj.description: no camping here! have to go to bennett gap
-NGp7YM_5gtV_OLqH9kj.name: Iza

-NGp7YMbFHVY8r7Rlt6D.description: not marked; you'll get to a sharp turn in the trail and be able to take a path down to the water. the water is kinda slimy
-NGp7YMbFHVY8r7Rlt6D.name: Iza

-NGp7YMc-66yHk9kmiT2.description: cell service definitely in the parking lot, suggested solo sites are on the loop coming out of the left of the parking lot and long the right trail (not through the meadow). suggest camping in the meadow; there's cell service and flat ground, but watch our for poison ivy there and at solo sites
-NGp7YMc-66yHk9kmiT2.name: Iza

-NGp7YMeFKAZcKlgVx6Z.description: campsites are on the trail up devils courthouse paved trail on the trail that stems out to the left going to the mountain to sea trail. there is also one on the side of the parking lot off the rock face. these are not the best, overgrown, and have thorns, but if you go to the right once up the rock face and keep walking down the trail for a few minutes, you can find some ok ones
-NGp7YMeFKAZcKlgVx6Z.name: Iza

-NGp7YMfS6hDnbUUXRPA.description: bear hang trees extremely difficult to find
-NGp7YMfS6hDnbUUXRPA.name: Iza

-NGp7YMg6D9OzunCRjnV.description:
The trails here that we use for the fun run are poorly marked. Basically you just want to take the trail North as much as you can until you get to a road. You *will* get to a road (Road 225) if you never decide to take a trail South. When we did the route this year, the path we took looked nothing like the map and spat us out on the road in a v different location from where we wanted to be. Just take that road all the way East. NEVER. TURN. LEFT. 

Also, DO NOT EXPECT TO DRIVE DOWN 225! This is how runners got lost in 2014. You can drive up 475B, but 225 is CLOSED. You'll have to park at this intersection.

So basically for the fun run, take the Cove Creek Trail north to 225, turn Right, follow 225 (which won't be marked) to 475B, go down 475B, turn right on the paved road, *make sure that the babies run in the left lane against traffic because #safety, and then turn right up into Cove. This year (2015) the route was 9.5 miles because the route to get from Cove to 225 was pretty long.

Also watch out for misogynist bear killing hunters that may heckle girls.
-NGp7YMg6D9OzunCRjnV.name: Addison Howenstine

-NGp7YMiLl_wNo2K7BrJ.description: The Bradley creek trail head is kinda hard to find. There's no sign or marker on it.  It's a moderately steep trail coming off the south side of the road. Obvi look at the map  when you're driving there. Its after the marked trail head on the north side of the road, and before the road blockage when you turn the corner. If you make it to some campsites called YG, that means yellow gap (too far). It is NOT through a campsite. Using parking lots to tell distance is ineffective (what even IS a parking lot in pisgah). Use the marked trail head to the north as a signal to slow down the convoy into search mode.
-NGp7YMiLl_wNo2K7BrJ.name: George Bernard

-NGp7YMjcgWQgloOzgXj.description:
There are some really awesome cliff overhangs here right where the trail splits off. Almost directly south of the intersection is a sheer cliff with some areas to sit and they're surrounded by blueberry bushes. I definitely recommend spending at least a few moments there taking in the view and enjoying the bounty.

If southbound, a left will take you to Shitfuck Ridge and a right will take you towards Devil's Courthous.
-NGp7YMjcgWQgloOzgXj.name: Michael Kim

-NGp7YMkgvR13UCag6eJ.description: You might think there would be camping at a place with a name like Saddle Gap. You would be wrong.
-NGp7YMkgvR13UCag6eJ.name: Jared

-NGp7YMmktW2JC7aIYq4.description: This is a tunnel. I believe tunnels are PWILD black zone. But in the winter the BRP might be closed, so then...it's okay? I don't know. But I'm marking it so that you think to discuss it before you hit the trail.
-NGp7YMmktW2JC7aIYq4.name: Ari Novick

-NGp7YMn8eDVsJUcZKJq.description: This mountain is EXHAUSTING. Make sure you know your crew before thinking about doing it the first day...
-NGp7YMn8eDVsJUcZKJq.name: Dusty H

-NGp7YMo9zw1bndktvB1.description: Some people may say that this is a route starting place. Do not trust them. This is false. The only way to get here is by ~hiking~
-NGp7YMo9zw1bndktvB1.name: Dusty H

-NGp7YMshfWxxBupP7L8.description: There's good camping down here by the river, but no good places for bear hangs and no good places to cook. Also, it's probably not ok to camp here ever again because of new Pisgah Bear rules, but just in case, keep this in mind.
-NGp7YMshfWxxBupP7L8.name: Dusty H

-NJIpr7pMTYxM7yyVNf2.description: Mountain man water spigot. The water might look a little cloudy but it's good. Make sure to fill up on water here if going into the backcountry overnight.
-NJIpr7pMTYxM7yyVNf2.name: Adam

-NJIr7UWakC_6wD3z9e-.description: Trailhead for the trail going up to Raccoon Mountain is hard to find, my crew completely missed it August 2022, though others were able to find it. Not that you would want to take that trail anyway... I heard it was ridiculously steep.
-NJIr7UWakC_6wD3z9e-.name: Adam

-NJIrpQ2EAkEU_P8U6f2.description: This trail is pretty steep. The hike up to Raven Knob is definitely worth it and the trail isn't too long, but if you're only doing it as a day hike your crewlings will appreciate not bringing their packs.
-NJIrpQ2EAkEU_P8U6f2.name: Adam

-NJIsgElcyO-EVydmsCH.description: Crewlings went on a hike around the lake in August 2022 looking for mangoes... :)
-NJIsgElcyO-EVydmsCH.name: Adam

-NJItLz-fOecTyqEwCZE.description: The big arena / amphitheater, big enough to fit all of PWILD several times over. We had final Jambo here in August 2022.
-NJItLz-fOecTyqEwCZE.name: Adam

-NJIv_ELOjNNWpzEb8nS.description:
If you don't have a clicker, you can trick the swift gate to open by wheeling the big black trash bin in front of the gate on the inside. The system thinks it's a car trying to leave, and opens the gate. Totally legit.

And by the way, that trash bin is fantastic for transporting stuff like sleeping bags between the locker and the parking lot (during gear prep/cleanup).
-NJIv_ELOjNNWpzEb8nS.name: Adam

-NJIxOeZdJvRxN-1xF7v.description: The crewlings love love loved swimming in August 2022. I'm pretty sure it was the favorite activity by far. FYI for if a PD ever plans to come back here.
-NJIxOeZdJvRxN-1xF7v.name: Adam

-NOQu7YxaP-NSY0rmVuw.name: Brennan
-NOQu7YxaP-NSY0rmVuw.text: Great campsite hear next to a stream with lots of water

-NQqnL1WIufgUaOfEi_n.name: Adam
-NQqnL1WIufgUaOfEi_n.text:
WARNING: We looked at this in March 2023, and there are dead trees within falling range of most of this campsite. It's possible you could find a spot for your tent just outside the range of a tree, but really this is better used as a lunch spot / kitchen.

One of the most gorgeous campsites I've ever seen by the way.

-NJJ0ofey77dIok0w5Cj.description: I heard that there's a great campsite just off the trail at this intersection.
-NJJ0ofey77dIok0w5Cj.name: Adam

-NJJ1X1JYwaxA06hWS5U.description: The map isn't lying, these are actual river crossings, no bridges. Not too deep, but definitely would flood your boots if you didn't take them off.
-NJJ1X1JYwaxA06hWS5U.name: Adam

-NJJ2RVo-Ym7vqQN14dE.description: In March 2022, a ranger warned us that the suspension bridge here was washed away, and it would be a while before it would get fixed. Until then, I understand you won't be able to cross the river on 133 here. Perhaps it's possible to ford it in August, but I wouldn't risk planning your route around that.
-NJJ2RVo-Ym7vqQN14dE.name: Adam

-NJJ3ikdO1VhiL0Dg58_.description: Camped here in March 2022, the only feasible camping along this blue stretch of 147. That said, you're basically camping right on the trail (which goes through the gap) / under the rhododendrons nearby, so not ideal.
-NJJ3ikdO1VhiL0Dg58_.name: Adam

-NJJ4lvXJRTMtigBLOMF.description: The forest along this trail is super gorgeous, especially in fall.
-NJJ4lvXJRTMtigBLOMF.name: Adam

-NJJ5wmTD25RJI5U9Etj.description: 360 degree VAMs from the trail, northward from here on the Art Loeb. This continues for quite a while, it's definitely worth coming to this area.
-NJJ5wmTD25RJI5U9Etj.name: Adam

-NJJ9gHnIRy-zEQmb75a.description: Camped here in March 2022. There's a clearing area where the road ends, and you can set up a tent just off the trail. Not an ideal campsite since you have to set up right by a trail / dirt road, but we didn't see anyone when we were there. Getting water from here was a little annoying.
-NJJ9gHnIRy-zEQmb75a.name: Adam

-NJJAO048MnFNF3awJ1F.description: Developed campsite here right by the river (with gravel tent pads). Are you allowed to camp here? Not sure. But we did in March 2022 and it was luxurious.
-NJJAO048MnFNF3awJ1F.name: Adam

-NJJGKcSOKMeHKvIFwOx.description: Cripple Creek Arch. "Mountain Man" and "Cripple Creek" seem to be used interchangeably on maps to mean this area.
-NJJGKcSOKMeHKvIFwOx.name: Adam

-NrEVIybw_2Tu90Xmql_.name: Adam
-NrEVIybw_2Tu90Xmql_.text: AllTrails photos confirm this is that spot, you would be able to camp here.

-NJJZ5ZZKRDC0AVceis1.description: There are a couple flatter places towards the middle of 322 where you could probably set up a camp. I don't remember exactly where but my guess is around this area based on the contour lines.
-NJJZ5ZZKRDC0AVceis1.name: Adam

-NejKcM7WerwyvMuyUu8.name: Aster
-NejKcM7WerwyvMuyUu8.text: I love the gear locker, hold onto it as best as you can future WILDers!

-NKgvFEO_qmODGaOvryk.description: The Gear Locker (in the parking garage). You can access it by taking the elevator down from the Lobby level. Unfortunately, you can't take the elevator back up, unless you have a DukeCard belonging to an RA or someone with a Swift parking pass. To get out, either go through the back door near the gate used for cars, or take the fire escape stairs leading to the front of swift (if you're outside the locker facing it, the stairs are behind you, all the way on the other side of the garage).
-NKgvFEO_qmODGaOvryk.name: Adam

-NKu_PnEE_bTV2QRBH0G.description: Somewhere around here was the site of the 2016 incident that got PWILD suspended for a year. Pro tip: don't block a trail with your packs because you want to go watersliding naked. Juicy details archived here: https://issuu.com/dukechronicle/docs/october_23__2017
-NKu_PnEE_bTV2QRBH0G.name: Adam

-NL-RgR54NyA7nTkvT1e.description: Accidentally left water filters hanging on a tree here in Fall 2022, didn’t realize until we got back to Duke.
-NL-RgR54NyA7nTkvT1e.name: Adam

-NL-TtoYlTSC57MDEqda.description: There’s a small clearing here where we set up camp in March 2022, in sight of two trails. Overall this gap didn’t seem so nice for camping, quite overgrown. Maybe there’s something better closer to the river, I don’t remember.
-NL-TtoYlTSC57MDEqda.name: Adam

-NL-VmkiE13dn5nCjPO8.description: BEAUTIFUL VAM. Bit of a hike to get here, especially since it’s an out and back trail, but so worth it. If you have less time, try the John Rock hike instead for a similar view.
-NL-VmkiE13dn5nCjPO8.name: Adam

-NL-WA6OZuhlslY7hFAm.description: Great VAM, view of Looking Glass Rock and the whole valley. Fun fact you can see Black Balsam from here.
-NL-WA6OZuhlslY7hFAm.name: Adam

-NL-ZgXyURPsnDVTB9i3.description: Mountain looks impressive, but unfortunately no views. Not really any good views on all of 322 for that matter (from Turkey Pen to Black Mountain).
-NL-ZgXyURPsnDVTB9i3.name: Adam

-NLFWnn_upZfc0JsrBbx.description: Campsite with shelter and wooden platforms, nice for screw games and life stories.
-NLFWnn_upZfc0JsrBbx.name: Unknown

-NLFX6euvaGh0gt3bv_M.description: Best view at Raven Knob. Steep hike up but nice rocky outcropping to admire the view and do lunch / life stories.
-NLFX6euvaGh0gt3bv_M.name: Unknown

-NLFXdYZ-Sr3FnNR0psb.description: GADU - where we did all gear prep for 2022. Don't prop the door open or DUPD will come.
-NLFXdYZ-Sr3FnNR0psb.name: Unknown

-NLFXvZv6vgfA5WDrwO1.description: Dog Quad - where we did welcome games and pack distribution in 2021 and 2022
-NLFXvZv6vgfA5WDrwO1.name: Unknown

-NLfzMLmEBqUJmkS9F4q.description: During the big thunderstorm in August 2022 on the first night,  my crew (aka best crew aka no nut crew) slept in this shelter, and Bach the dog joined us. He was too heavy to roll off my legs, and he snored all night. Best night ever
-NLfzMLmEBqUJmkS9F4q.name: Aster B.

-NQqiaWEwalRCycjyyB7.name: Adam
-NQqiaWEwalRCycjyyB7.text: Didn't see this connection when hiking the Art Loeb in March 2023, but we could have just missed it. There was a marked connection to 471D further along the Art Loeb (see other Pro-Tip point).

-NM-Va84QiE7lmpXFXxQ.description: Note that 471D connects to Low Gap here (aka 'I Can't Believe It's Not Butter Gap')
-NM-Va84QiE7lmpXFXxQ.name: Klaudia Cabinles

-NM-VuyuSf-qy55bMSRx.description: When coming up the road, there is a sharp left with a social trail that continues forward(ish). Follow this to get to two large group campsites with running water.
-NM-VuyuSf-qy55bMSRx.name: Klaudia Cabinles

-NP0-yPfahksZJDx3J_V.description: Had to set up our tent at a moderate impact site right next to the trail in March 2022 to get out of a downpour. The tent was right next to the trail, and we had to walk a bit off trail to get to water.
-NP0-yPfahksZJDx3J_V.name: Brennan

-NQqkbbJyvO-oc8lnoy1.name: Adam
-NQqkbbJyvO-oc8lnoy1.text: Wow, this is a gorgeous waterfall - gentle cascade for 15 feet or so down a rock face. There's a short path leading down from the trail. On satellite view, it's marked as "Falls on Grogan Creek"

-NP00BbARJkHEB068dN-.description: Beautiful waterfall that was full after rains!
-NP00BbARJkHEB068dN-.name: Brennan

-NbfiDowSwNahPYkXWHS.name: Adam
-NbfiDowSwNahPYkXWHS.text: The VAM is through trees, so it's possible you won't see that much in August (compared to March)

-NP00QaK0FNusRbWpfNR.description: Steep hill to walk up (from Low Gap), but this has a great VAM and is also a nice place to eat lunch
-NP00QaK0FNusRbWpfNR.name: Brennan

-NP00vVA78rrBy1If5j4.description: Beautiful VAM's along the hike up to the BRP!
-NP00vVA78rrBy1If5j4.name: Brennan

-NQqo6LXZUOYFHVHgaQg.name: Adam
-NQqo6LXZUOYFHVHgaQg.text: Update March 2023 - bridge has been fixed.

-NP01C5xeHkREq54QiVl.description: Bridge over the creek here was washed out or not put out during March 2022. Had to jump between stones to get across.
-NP01C5xeHkREq54QiVl.name: Brennan

-NQp0yJER3H-P1PEFLoD.description: Correction – the water is NOT slimy. Swam here in March 2023, the water was wonderfully clear and there is a nice sandy area next to the hole for drying off in the sun.
-NQp0yJER3H-P1PEFLoD.name: Brennan

-NQp18EzOdJHYYHSr1mE.description: More river crossings along here, including a couple deeper sections that you need to take your boots off for.
-NQp18EzOdJHYYHSr1mE.name: Brennan

-NbqgnpK990Q3oWm9K_K.name: Brennan
-NbqgnpK990Q3oWm9K_K.text: No real campsites from here until the intersection with 118A to the north

-NQp1KubuYTce4k6evT9.description: Great campsite here (enough room for 1 smaller tent)! There were logs for sitting around a previously used fire pit. There were also multiple streams nearby for easy water access.
-NQp1KubuYTce4k6evT9.name: Brennan

-NQp1ZcoJSoHrppgQpfh.description: Great campsite area here. Lots of flat areas for tents plus a central cooking area, and there was a nearby creek for water. Be careful about camping under dead trees.
-NQp1ZcoJSoHrppgQpfh.name: Brennan

-NQp1xH_4dt5MDc3TNxp.description: We luckily found a great developed campsite here! Most of this trail section is on a steep hillside, but this was the one site that had a nice flat place for a tent. Water is about 1/4 mile away in either direction.
-NQp1xH_4dt5MDc3TNxp.name: Brennan

-NQp2ec7_1ny25lNyz03.description: Wonderful VAMs along the trail here of much of Pisgah!
-NQp2ec7_1ny25lNyz03.name: Brennan

-NUJlDCDCz2lK2Ls8QY4.name: Aster
-NUJlDCDCz2lK2Ls8QY4.text: ^* this guy topped Mt. Pisgah and your mom

-NQp2m_ZPHi5lzfn1nZ2.description: The trail to the top of Mount Pisgah is very steep, but the VAMs at the top are well-worth it!
-NQp2m_ZPHi5lzfn1nZ2.name: Brennan

-NQqYqHhsuXjWckWsjDL.description: Spectacular VAM in a small rocky clearing along the trail at the very top of Pilot Mountain. Good views in both March and August. Great place to stop for lunch.
-NQqYqHhsuXjWckWsjDL.name: Adam

-NQqZ4KRQlQf1V1_03qx.description: In March, this trail (between Deep Gap and Pilot Mountain peak) has amazing VAMs all the way, because the trees don't have leaves.
-NQqZ4KRQlQf1V1_03qx.name: Adam

-NQq_U1ZkN4i8zYH3N3N.description: There is a broken bridge here that appears to lead west, which is a bit confusing. That bridge is not part of the trail. Just follow the sign for Daniel Ridge Loop and you'll be fine.
-NQq_U1ZkN4i8zYH3N3N.name: Adam

-Nabsx1FTzEKOpOP1KKa.name: Aster
-Nabsx1FTzEKOpOP1KKa.text: Can confirm, this part is tough!

-NQqa-ocZfK4eH2sR9by.description: Challenging river crossing on big boulders / rushing water that is sketchy to wade in. It took us a while to find a way across in March 2023. To be safe, add at least 30 min to your time estimate to cross here, especially if it's rained recently.
-NQqa-ocZfK4eH2sR9by.name: Adam

-NQqb3884OZ0AcLsxFKh.description: Somewhat high impact campsite here right by the trail, near the water source. Only really enough flat space for a tent/tarp I think (for smellable safety, kitchen would probably need to be somewhere else, maybe by the creek).
-NQqb3884OZ0AcLsxFKh.name: Adam

-NQqcf0kBYMhrDq3Q1Ej.description: Yikes this climb is very steep. And it stays like that for quite a long while. This is doable but painful. Also keep this in mind if you are coming up 106 to camp at Farlow - it will be at the end of a day of mostly uphill.
-NQqcf0kBYMhrDq3Q1Ej.name: Adam

-NQqczJfkZlyoRXnnrbB.description: Very very steep trail, that stays that way for a long time. It's much easier to hike Pilot Mountain southbound on the Art Loeb than northbound.
-NQqczJfkZlyoRXnnrbB.name: Adam

-NQqgwz3DAkOm1dgjm5n.description: Trails are confusing around here, small trails leading towards Cedar Rock Mountain not marked on the Nat Geo. Look for blazes (blue for Butter Gap trail aka 123, white for Art Loeb) to help navigate.
-NQqgwz3DAkOm1dgjm5n.name: Adam

-NQqiJz8CdqwPvSDYNof.description: The parallel blue / Art Loeb trails here are marked incorrectly on the Nat Geo - they actually run parallel east to west. Also, at this point there is a connection path to the 471D road, indicated by a sign (not marked on the Nat Geo). See the Open Street Map (OSM) layer for a more accurate trail map of this intersection.
-NQqiJz8CdqwPvSDYNof.name: Adam

-NQqmmyCu5lMub5QvQm-.description: Cedar Rock Creek Falls!! Majestic waterfall, one of my favorites, definitely worth a visit. See google maps for images. It's easy to miss if you're not looking for it. A few hundred yards to the east of the 120/123 intersection, start listening for the sound of a waterfall. There are two tiny paths down through the rhododendrons. I think one of the entrances was close to a mini landslide. Consider not bringing your packs all the way down, the access trails are very narrow and very steep.
-NQqmmyCu5lMub5QvQm-.name: Adam

-NQqo0-yPXZu_VOybJ0B.description:
Picklesimer Fields is COVERED with DEAD trees. This is true along most of the lowland sections of trails 123 and 120 (probably 116 too). Many many spots that look like good campsites at first, have dead trees over them. Be very careful when picking a campsite.

Also - dead branches on alive trees are a hazard too. Some largish ones fell near our tent in March 2023.
-NQqo0-yPXZu_VOybJ0B.name: Adam

-NQqoju1M2EwsPM6o9Dj.description: There are some spots here that look like attractive campsites, but be careful about dead trees. Also I suspect we're not allowed to camp here anyways because it's too close to a road? And one of the "campsites" had a no camping sign at it.
-NQqoju1M2EwsPM6o9Dj.name: Adam

-NQqoxJj9rr-12pOWG41.description: There are a couple small clearings on either side of the trail here that make good campsites / kitchens. With good tent placement you can be out of range of dead trees / dead branches. Camped here in March 2023.
-NQqoxJj9rr-12pOWG41.name: Adam

-NQqpUuD4Lu7u0Jci2WE.description: There's a waterfall here that's much smaller than Cedar Rock Creek Falls, but still nice to spend time at. To access - there's a steep trail going down to the river just to the east of the intersection, into what looks like a campsite (BUT ISN"T, big dead tree).
-NQqpUuD4Lu7u0Jci2WE.name: Adam

-NQqpqZ5pV9SGkS49r8B.description: Creepy gray abandoned sleeping bag in the bushes here. Gave us a fright at night in March 2023.
-NQqpqZ5pV9SGkS49r8B.name: Adam

-NQqqNBy_83gO4kpTCTg.description: No cell service here / in nearby areas. In March 2023 they left a van in the parking lot in case of emergency.
-NQqqNBy_83gO4kpTCTg.name: Adam

-NQqqklkzmlLqnnGASml.description: There seemed to be a decent campsite to the west of the trail here, in the open woods. Not sure since we didn't go to look, but it looked pretty flat and open.
-NQqqklkzmlLqnnGASml.name: Adam

-NQqrQvD2cwE9hqf6t6c.description: Camped here in March 2023 in a 4 person tent. You wouldn't be able to fit an August crew at this gap, flat spots are very limited / small. Also all right on the trail. Might have difficulty fitting a six person tent, but is maybe doable with squish?
-NQqrQvD2cwE9hqf6t6c.name: Adam

-NQqtgcGVpNxernMtJxG.description: Beautiful hike through tall mountain laurel bushes - enchanted vibes.
-NQqtgcGVpNxernMtJxG.name: Adam

-NQqunKU6lbaZw3cN2KY.description: In March 2023, saw crows (or ravens?) carrying ice in their feet and beaks as they swooped through the air.
-NQqunKU6lbaZw3cN2KY.name: Adam

-NUJm4mxDOoV2tA1hUSW.name: Aster
-NUJm4mxDOoV2tA1hUSW.text:
We saw someone get proposed here this March! It was a great place for base camp to eat some torts and tangerines and do tangerine yoga.

We saw people taking wedding pictures the March before, so definitely a wholesome place

-NQqwpzmxSGtcTTWXv2x.description: One of the most magnificent waterfalls I've seen in my life. Definitely ask to stop here during a drop off / pick up.
-NQqwpzmxSGtcTTWXv2x.name: Adam

-NS4h-nNc_DbwroYUhJ-.description: Site of Cove during PWILD August 2021, we reserved all the group campsites.
-NS4h-nNc_DbwroYUhJ-.name: Adam

-NZgu2i-hNtbv0LTHpxe.description: Just when you think you’re done going up hill you go up another hill
-NZgu2i-hNtbv0LTHpxe.name: Rohan Bose

-NZguw8lQsJDNuPWn9NP.description: Don’t pee into the wind here it ended poorly
-NZguw8lQsJDNuPWn9NP.name: Rohan Bose

-NabsgfvKM7qLkc26zUm.description: This is an awesome loop, especially the northern portion with its waterfall/river! Big caveat: There is no service at all on this trail even for Verizon, so time drop-offs and pick-ups carefully.
-NabsgfvKM7qLkc26zUm.name: Aster

-NbW95eGp8999ZRkgBP1.description: Great campsite, babbling brook, 10/10. Could probably fit a large tarp here?
-NbW95eGp8999ZRkgBP1.name: Andrew

-NbqiNSnPpydSC5JxsXj.description: Buckhorn gap is a reservable, established campsite, so do not count on this campsite being open.
-NbqiNSnPpydSC5JxsXj.name: Brennan

-NbqkRxdz66oZi7-l-t1.description: We didn't camp here, but there are several small-medium campsites along trail 602 near the creek.
-NbqkRxdz66oZi7-l-t1.name: Brennan

-NbvgUeXnRXYeQd9IW_D.description: Pretty established campsite here that is large enough for 1-2 tarps
-NbvgUeXnRXYeQd9IW_D.name: Jack Proudfoot via Adam

-NcTwdJONTy9vOn5ULpg.description: Little creek to fill up on water a short walk from the start of the closed road 5003. Takes about six minutes to get there and is decently close to the campsite on the art lobe trail
-NcTwdJONTy9vOn5ULpg.name: Alba Uriarte

-NeBoFRRJUEjvyyjiE8Q.name: Adam
-NeBoFRRJUEjvyyjiE8Q.text: Most spots have only enough contiguous flat ground for a tent / multiple tents (and there are a lot of these spots). The two/three largest campsites can fit a tarp though.

-NcnhMxvlgESA409s_hb.description: Several great campsites with lots of space to spread out next to the creek along this stretch of trail. Be sure to look out for dead trees.
-NcnhMxvlgESA409s_hb.name: Brennan

-NcnhUmvTNP62BmSgYRe.description: Beautiful waterfalls along this stretch of trail, with VAMs of the valley bellow as well!
-NcnhUmvTNP62BmSgYRe.name: Brennan

-Ncni5295lNY6Oq90hIL.description: A decently reliable spot for finding water, even in drier summer months. Go to the second switchback down this trail from the Art Loeb and the creek should have enough volume for filtering.
-Ncni5295lNY6Oq90hIL.name: Brennan

-NdOC8iJTJeS_Z57Yk78.name: Adam
-NdOC8iJTJeS_Z57Yk78.text: If you explore around enough, you can find deciduous trees that are adequate for bear hangs (the conifers are a bit too branchy).

-NcniMU2u78_Q0VPBVQu.description: A couple of good campsites here in the general vicinity of this trail junction with enough space to spread out a tarp. These are relatively protected by trees.
-NcniMU2u78_Q0VPBVQu.name: Brennan

-Ncni_Q0z35epmWEfAlG.description: Beautiful VAMs along the Art Loeb here, but the trail can be quite overgrown with blueberry bushes in the late summer.
-Ncni_Q0z35epmWEfAlG.name: Brennan

-NcnnZUQl86qM0u7wT1y.description: Very tempting nice campsites in this area, but most of them have dead trees. Try to avoid sleeping there.
-NcnnZUQl86qM0u7wT1y.name: Maya Reeves

-Nco0LVklyD6SRAWhF1n.description: Absolutely gorgeous view!!! One of the prettiest spots in all of Pisgah in my opinion
-Nco0LVklyD6SRAWhF1n.name: Adam

-Nco16q7dglLGvPTNQkJ.description: Super beautiful view, you can see forever!! Highest point in the area of Pisgah that PWILD visits
-Nco16q7dglLGvPTNQkJ.name: Adam

-Nco1Y5Q7MgIhWIJXP3f.description: This is actually quite a beautiful trail, shaded woods but still with views. Nice if your crew is tired and doesn’t want to go over Grassy Cove Top. Also I think it’s marked as an equestrian trail but is really a foot trail, and a bit overgrown in spots
-Nco1Y5Q7MgIhWIJXP3f.name: Adam

-Nco2Kw_KQY3cL3aW9mD.description: You can camp here, Katie did so in Fall 2019. Looks rather exposed and with few trees from satellite view, so probably only for tent camping in good weather?
-Nco2Kw_KQY3cL3aW9mD.name: Katie Knotek via Adam

-Nco9q0c_qMzBqO5-dsT.description: In August 2023 we were told by some hikers that there was recent bear activity in this area
-Nco9q0c_qMzBqO5-dsT.name: Adam

-NcoACSfp9qCfwsXua30.description: We saw giant bear claw marks on a tree here in August 2023, evidence of bears in the area
-NcoACSfp9qCfwsXua30.name: Adam

-NcrnWpRFwCchOgleUnT.description: Two rattlesnakes were spotted on the path to John Rock. According to Gurnoor, this is quite rare and may indicate a nearby nest.
-NcrnWpRFwCchOgleUnT.name: Sam

-NdqhRna2U0fj0cuh-BS.name: Adam
-NdqhRna2U0fj0cuh-BS.text: A small trickle of a stream was found here in March 2023 several days after it rained. So seems very rain dependent.

-Ncro4R0jLnNdRDlfFGP.description: According to our route sheet, there can be water found in this area coming from a pipe. However, Pisgah was fairly dry during the August trip so no water was found.
-Ncro4R0jLnNdRDlfFGP.name: Sam

-NcrpGcdvwzk8ojExRL3.description: Established campsite near the summit of Rich Mountain. There is a branch off the Art Loeb trail that leads to a nice campsite with a campfire and logs for sitting. Not many dead trees. Trek Crews 3 and 5 had a fun mini Jambo here during August 2023.
-NcrpGcdvwzk8ojExRL3.name: Sam

-Ncrpj_xhEIv1kSnd5WZ.description: We met Nathan at this intersection. He told us the meaning of type 2 fun and hired one of crewlings for the climbing wall. He said the path up to John Rock was only 15 minutes... It took like an hour.
-Ncrpj_xhEIv1kSnd5WZ.name: Sam

-NcrqJCCNIPzk8Z0qcUX.description: There's a creek by the parking lot. Our crewlings did a polar plunge here to appease the Pisgods after many struggles from Day 1.
-NcrqJCCNIPzk8Z0qcUX.name: Sam

-Ncs1oi85D1ce3b2pMDY.description: Here, we thought we had forgotten our water filters and needed a base camp drop-off. Turns out a crewling had it the whole time.
-Ncs1oi85D1ce3b2pMDY.name: Sam

-NdNxJQtJyELddx8sLnK.description: AMAZING VAM, you can see a huge amount of the lower areas in Pisgah from here. Fair warning that this overlook is often in a cloud, so try to come on a day with blue skies.
-NdNxJQtJyELddx8sLnK.name: Adam

-NdNxmJ4KlOnnzo1oxPf.description: 347 actually intersects the Mountains to Sea Trail here, not further west as is shown on the Nat Geo. Can be confusing for crewlings wondering why the trail goes east so much before seeing this intersection. See the Open Street Map (OSM) layer for accurate intersection.
-NdNxmJ4KlOnnzo1oxPf.name: Adam

-NdX96OMpX9xsa1drjwr.name: Adam
-NdX96OMpX9xsa1drjwr.text: Brennan came here and agrees that this is only suitable for tent camping, not tarps. Although probably the Shining Rock Gap sites are better for either since they’re much more sheltered.

-NeKCyc8xuDvYIJVoGcO.name: Adam
-NeKCyc8xuDvYIJVoGcO.text: Also this is on top of a peak in addition to being exposed, so not good for lightning safety and likely quite windy.

-NdOADj1b7sSgTpmhzsp.description: This is "Shining Rock Campground." I didn't walk all the way up to this since there were other good campsites at Shining Rock Gap, but some other hikers mentioned this as another good camping option. From satellite view it looks a bit open - probably tent camping. The sites near Shining Rock Gap are under largish trees, and probably better for tarps.
-NdOADj1b7sSgTpmhzsp.name: Adam

-NdOG5r-guKa8nM5BIOT.description: There's one camping spot around here that might work for a small tent, but not too many other campsites on this bit of trail, very dense undergrowth. I think there might have also been a campsite at the intersection with 347 but I could be wrong about that, didn't check closely.
-NdOG5r-guKa8nM5BIOT.name: Adam

-NdOGbz48oq_Z40eaku3.description: BEAUTIFUL WILDFLOWER FIELD! Tons of wild carrot in August 2023, plus sweeping vistas.
-NdOGbz48oq_Z40eaku3.name: Adam

-NdOIasbSpnmfB03xWt6.description: Ripe blueberry bushes everywhere around Tennent Mountain in August!
-NdOIasbSpnmfB03xWt6.name: Adam

-NdOJI0C_mcYiBks74if.description: Make sure you have plenty of water before heading north on the Art Loeb from here. The balds are very exposed and dehydrating, especially in summer. Closest water source to the north is Shining Rock Gap, and that's quite a ways away.
-NdOJI0C_mcYiBks74if.name: Adam

-NdOJlB72izZbu582jlW.description: This intersection is hard to find, completely didn't see it in August 2023.
-NdOJlB72izZbu582jlW.name: Adam

-NdOKgtZ574O2eKBlZwY.description: Gorgeous gentle waterfall and two absolutely wonderful swimming holes! One of the prettiest spots on this trail in my opinion.
-NdOKgtZ574O2eKBlZwY.name: Adam

-NdOLIUo4giYZlV2kEOP.description: This creek crossing will probably be completely impossible if it's rained recently and this valley's creeks are flooding. You have to clamber over large rocks that very likely have rapids rushing through/over them when in flood.
-NdOLIUo4giYZlV2kEOP.name: Adam

-NdOLf563g7Nvpr2I8ke.description: This is a really majestic river gorge, huge rocks and lots of smaller waterfalls. Great hike for awesome WAMs (water appreciation moments).
-NdOLf563g7Nvpr2I8ke.name: Adam

-NdOMgOGKD3YhbMNLmIU.description: Somewhere along here, the trail is very eroded away into the river bed (in August 2023). There's one particularly precarious spot where half the trail is literally gone, replaced by a cliff 10-15 ft down into the river. You have to slowly inch by, holding onto bushes to make sure you don't fall. In other eroded sections hikers have created a new sketchy trail that has a sharp sideways slope, also above a significant drop into the river. Probably a bad idea to hike this section when it's wet, slipping on mud here and falling could cause quite bad injuries.
-NdOMgOGKD3YhbMNLmIU.name: Adam

-NdON2ONHUK6fYJcew4N.description: There are like 5-6 amazing looking high-impact campsites in this vicinity, but in August 2023 they all had at least one dead tree within falling range. So not really recommended to camp here. Also FYI in August 2023 there was a homeless person's stuff in a cave by the eastern trail, near the parking lot.
-NdON2ONHUK6fYJcew4N.name: Adam

-NdOOcq0z141U6wLb0eK.description: Don't send a crew up either these trails unless everyone is actually an athlete. It goes up for the full 4 miles, and very steep for long stretches. A beginner PWILD crew would probably not make it up to Shining Rock Gap.
-NdOOcq0z141U6wLb0eK.name: Adam

-NdOPbdMdOGFVIKF9VL7.description: I haven't been here, but according to AllTrails there are some pretty spectacular VAMs from the top. Hike looks steep though, consider making this a day hike.
-NdOPbdMdOGFVIKF9VL7.name: Adam

-NdORBLwpYLORuBfF8mV.description: There are pretty much no water sources in this area. If you plan to hike Mount Pisgah, consider coordinating a water drop with base camp on the Blue Ridge Parkway. Or decide to have a really long mileage day.
-NdORBLwpYLORuBfF8mV.name: Adam

-NdORhUnY7CTrrtjROMY.description: There's a campsite somewhere around here, on the left if you're heading north. Lots of roots, so only really enough flat space for a tent (not a tarp).
-NdORhUnY7CTrrtjROMY.name: Adam

-NdOSec8fNSPQ3uot_S3.description: No camping allowed in Graveyard Fields because of bear activity, large fine if you do it. Black Balsam area and Shining Rock Wilderness are ok. See here for details: https://www.nps.gov/places/graveyard-fields.htm
-NdOSec8fNSPQ3uot_S3.name: Adam

-NdOYwE4_vVOuUeSXC-R.description: Someone's nalgene rolled off John Rock
-NdOYwE4_vVOuUeSXC-R.name: Hayden

-NdXCtvS3ZKDrSpnPaDC.description: If you choose to camp at Neil Gap along the Art Loeb, you can walk through the brush down to this service road. There is a pipe under the road that sometimes has water in it. We found water here in March 2022 after a rainstorm.
-NdXCtvS3ZKDrSpnPaDC.name: Brennan

-NdXDWIQnIPQCMzf8yzf.description: Another potential source of water if you are camping at Gloucester Gap. Walk southwest down road 475 until you see a pipe going under the road. The stream had enough water for filtration in March 2022 (after significant rains).
-NdXDWIQnIPQCMzf8yzf.name: Brennan

-NdxdG3bD8sk6S4HMm4y.description: In August 2023, explore crews swam in the pools beneath the falls and loved it a lot
-NdxdG3bD8sk6S4HMm4y.name: Adam

-NeBrxUR44l_5_2PVK6O.description: According to satellite view, there is a sizeable high-impact campsite here. Looks quite exposed though, probably best suited for tent camping in decent weather.
-NeBrxUR44l_5_2PVK6O.name: Adam

-NeKDfDgyp3kihVzlYDo.description: Potential campsite here on a trail spur, according to satellite view?
-NeKDfDgyp3kihVzlYDo.name: Adam

-Nh_IdVrC8P9lKJiYCyi.description:
The second-largest campsite in Sam Knob Valley is here, but kind of hidden. (Largest campsite is marked with the solos point further west). If you're walking west on the trail, after you cross the tributary creek and keep walking for a few hundred feet, there's an open "campsite"-looking area to your right on Flat Laurel Creek (but with a dead tree). If you instead go up the hill to your left, you will find the campsite. It's a beautiful open glade area with lots of grass and a large high-impact tarp spot.

We used the creek-side "campsite" as a kitchen, which was very pleasant and convenient.
-Nh_IdVrC8P9lKJiYCyi.name: Adam

-NrCQ3GzAB2TEVvSBmn-.description: The Blue Ridge Parkway (BRP) is sometimes known as the "burp"...
-NrCQ3GzAB2TEVvSBmn-.name: Word of Mouth

-NrEE5zCnW_QDRcGlTXH.description: Billy Branch Falls (see AllTrails for pics)
-NrEE5zCnW_QDRcGlTXH.name: Adam

-NrEEy2whN60gsXVeJwI.description: Twin Falls - a very large, tall waterfall. Definitely worth a visit.
-NrEEy2whN60gsXVeJwI.name: Adam

-NrEGBuZJB_7bjbhkhHi.description: Looking through the AllTrails photos suggests there are good campsites in this vicinity, but I haven't been so can't confirm. Might require some exploring.
-NrEGBuZJB_7bjbhkhHi.name: Adam

-NrEGlvINmR7-QDoYcCp.description: There is a flat meadow here - might be good for camping? AllTrails photo from April 2022 shows it is flat/open with low grass.
-NrEGlvINmR7-QDoYcCp.name: Adam

-NrEIfDSch7Vr0Ve8Qct.description: According to one AllTrails photo, there is a large, flat, sheltered campsite here - good for tarps or tents. This is assuming the photo location was marked correctly, but the contour lines seem to support this.
-NrEIfDSch7Vr0Ve8Qct.name: Adam

-NrEJPq83yrXcFKFwuDJ.description: Small high-impact campsite here according to AllTrails.
-NrEJPq83yrXcFKFwuDJ.name: Adam

-NrEK9fatlMPlRXMtiWc.description: Narrow but impressive VAM through a gap in the trees. In winter this trail in general has good VAMs because no leaves.
-NrEK9fatlMPlRXMtiWc.name: Adam

-NrES3utgUhH45KyFDYe.description: Gently sloping waterfall over some large rocks.
-NrES3utgUhH45KyFDYe.name: Adam

-NrEXOhSb1-c4dfUJysh.description: Fantastic VAMs in this area (Pilot Rock).
-NrEXOhSb1-c4dfUJysh.name: Adam

-NrMw2-vpZe4CkP0JVzo.description: There is a gate here that is usually closed. Maybe you'll get lucky and it won't be? But I doubt it. Makes driving from Pink Beds to Gloucester Gap take extra long.
-NrMw2-vpZe4CkP0JVzo.name: Adam

-NrN15TndFv348V1Edgv.description: Really beautiful trees and spring wildflowers!
-NrN15TndFv348V1Edgv.name: Adam
